channel.title: Code Formatting
channel.description: I see everyone has their own code formatting set up, some have more indents than other etc. this isn't good as each time someone works with a class (or multiple) they like to auto format the code to their layout, which means in git when i'm looking over things, theres a LOT of changes which is very annoying. we need to all stick with some sort of formatting and leave it at that, cause this just won't work.

item.title: Code Formatting
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

I just use the default formatting the Eclipse does… It follows conventions, and I like the way it formats the code.

As for not mixing things, that’s kind of hard to do when pull requests take days to be answered… I’m not going to sit around doing nothing useful after I’ve re-factored a few classes.

item.title: Code Formatting
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

Soft tabs (s/\t+/ /g). That should eliminate a lot of the noise that you see in commit messages. I will try to submit a version of the source formatted in this way within the next day or two.

Another thing that makes it easier on the people who review submissions - the following three things should preferably never be mixed:

  1. Refactoring (variable/class names)
  2. Formatting changes (mainly referring to whitespace)
  3. Actual, important changes to the source code (logic or otherwise)

It is alright to mix 1 and 2 occasionally, but try to keep that to a minimum.
